modules.description: This module defines core type signatures for persistent storage abstractions, including operations for key-value lookups, iteration, and transactional updates. It works with structured data types such as tables, references, and polymorphic values, supporting persistence across sessions. Concrete use cases include implementing custom storage backends for application state, caching mechanisms, and durable data stores with atomic modifications.

This module implements persistent references that can be stored and retrieved asynchronously. It works with a store module parameter to provide `ref`, `get`, and `set` operations for values of any type `'a`. Concrete use cases include managing shared, mutable state across requests in a web application with persistence backed by a storage engine.

This module defines variable-like structures with lazy initialization, supporting both synchronous and Lwt-based asynchronous default value computation. It operates on key-value pairs where keys and values are determined by the parameter module T. Concrete use cases include managing persistent state with deferred initialization, such as caching or configuration values that are loaded on demand.

This module converts a functorial interface into a polymorphic one, enabling operations on persistent tables with string keys and arbitrary values. It supports opening tables, querying, inserting, updating, and removing entries, along with iteration and folding over table contents, all with Lwt-based asynchronous handling. Use cases include managing shared, persistent key-value stores across threads with precise control over data lifecycle and consistency.

This module enables the creation of custom persistent storage implementations with support for key-value operations, transactions, and asynchronous handling. It works with structured types like tables, references, and polymorphic values to manage application state, caches, and durable data stores. Concrete uses include implementing storage backends with atomic updates, shared persistent key-value stores, and lazy-initialized configuration values.
